Hi Ken,

Before getting to my question, a belated congratulations on your PhD!
 A much deserved honor, I'm sure.

I'm just getting around to making the changes for our implementation
of NEAT to do mutations more like yours; i.e., at most one topological
mutation can occur per individual per generation.  Here's my question:

> "In smaller populations, the probability of adding a new node was 
> 0.03 and the probability of a new link mutation was 0.05. In the 
> larger population, the probability of adding a new link was 0.3."

> As for the final question of whether you can add a link and a node 
> at the same time, in my system you can't.  However, it would hardly 
> make a difference.  What makes a difference is adding big globs of 
> structure all at once vs. adding just one or on a rare occasion two 
> pieces.

Given a population, we have 2 sets of mutated individuals.  3% get a
new node, 5% get a new connection.  How do you handle the intersection
if no individuals can have both?  I can see 2 ways of doing it.

1) For those that would get 2 mutations, flip a coin and choose one. 
This would mean that slightly fewer than 3% and 5% are actually
getting the mutation.  
2) Ensure there is no intersection.  Take 8% of the population to be
mutated, then to 5/8 of those add a connection and to 3/8 add a node.
   This could get counterintuitive with larger mutation rates; e.g.,
if we had a 60% rate for add node and 60% rate for add connection,
we'd actally wind up with 50% for both.

It's a fine point, and won't matter much if we always use very small
mutation rates.  But I'd like my imlementation to make sense even if
we decide to have larger rates, and I want it to be as close to yours
as possible for comparing results.

Thanks,
Philip
